awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Pteridological Collections Consortium: An integrative approach to pteridophyte diversity over the last 420 million years
awd_abstract_narration:
Ferns and their relatives ("pteridophytes") arose approximately 420 million years ago and were the dominant plant groups for hundreds of millions of years afterwards. Today the pteridophytes are outnumbered by the diversity and abundance of other plant groups, such as those that bear flowers, but they remain diverse (with around 12,000 species), ecologically important, and are found throughout the world. This Thematic Collections Network (TCN) brings together 9 core institutions whose goal is to make digital images and data on the distribution and biology of 1.6 million fossil and modern ferns and their relatives available to researchers. This effort includes 39 US Museums and Herbaria that will provide on-line access of collections data to researchers worldwide who will be able to address pressing questions about the evolution, distribution, and biology of land plants.  This project would train students and reach the public through teacher training opportunities, the development of curriculum and education boxes and through the production of informative science videos. 

The Pteridological Collections Consortium TCN is an interdisciplinary initiative that will database, image, and disseminate information on an unprecedented number of extant and fossil pteridophyte specimens. The combining of neo- and paleobotanical collections data will produce an online resource via a Symbiota framework to enable research on the distribution, ecology, genetics, and deep-time evolution of an important group of vascular plants. Pteridophytes are important because they 1) are relatively diverse and have extensive global distributions, 2) are associated with evolutionary innovations that shaped adaptations to terrestrial ecosystems, 3) they are sensitive to local environmental conditions and play important roles in modern communities, and 4) they have an excellent fossil record for addressing deep-time questions. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Pteridophytes, the spore bearing ferns and their close relatives, arose over 400 million years ago and played an important role in forming many terrestrial ecosystems. With approximately 12,000 living species today, pteridophytes remain the most diverse major group of non-flowering land plants and are ecologically important in many habitats throughout the world.  Herbarium and fossil collections curated within natural history institutions document the occurrence of these plants on Earth over time, enabling the study of their diversity, geographic distribution, and evolution. By digitizing them and integrating their data online, this project has provided researchers worldwide with access to an unprecedented resource to study pteridophytes and their role in the evolution and persistence of terrestrial ecosystems, especially in response to potential environmental change.

This Thematic Collections Network (TCN), led by the University of California at Berkeley, brought together nine core institutions, including the University of Florida, with the goal of making digital images and data on the distribution and biology of 1.6 million fossil and modern pteridophytes available to researchers. This effort included 39 US Museums and Herbaria that provided on-line access of collections data to researchers worldwide who will be able to address pressing questions about the evolution, distribution, and biology of land plants. The PCC project's primary goal was to image and digitize the metadata for over 1.6 million herbarium and 100,000 fossil pteridophyte specimens, and to provide free, online access to them through a dedicated PCC data portal, for use by researchers, educators, and the general public. The specimen data and images generated by this award and the PCC project as a whole are also now openly accessible through the online Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) and the Integrated Digitized Biocollections.

This project trained students and reached the public through teacher training opportunities, the development of curricula, and through the production of educational videos. At the University of Florida, training and employment was provided to undergraduates and graduate students who were instructed on digital imaging, data transcription, and how to handle biological collections. This training and employment offered and important step for early-career researchers in STEM disciplines. 

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: John G Burleigh
